Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: OSTARA: An Optically-based Simultaneous Transmit And Receive Architecture for Enhancing Wireless Communications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Improving the usage of communication spectrum resources is critical to future wireless systems. The OSTARA project focuses on the development of RF photonic techniques that support the ability to simultaneously transmit and receive in wireless devices. The effort involves a mix of theoretical development (specifically investigating potential improvements in capacity), as well as systems validation efforts involving building an opto-cancellation circuit capable of cancelling out co-site interference associated with simultaneous transmission and reception. . Specifically, the theoretical component of the effort will involve using ray-tracing to understand the role of cancelation of multipath components on communication rate, as well as an investigation into the impact of idealized cancellation on network capacity using graph coloring. The systems component of the effort will involve developing photonic circuits that subtract off the transmitted signal from the receiver chain, as well as potential multipath images of the transmitted signal. Validation will involve field testing the opto-canceller by setting up test scenarios on the ORBIT testbed at WINLAB.

Broader Impact: The proposed research will improve the spectrum utilization of future wireless systems, an issue of critical national importance. Additionally, the project will educate students and post-doctoral fellows in the inter-disciplinary area of RF-photonics as applied to advanced radio systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The OSTARA project was focused on improving the technical operation of wireless communication systems to allow for them to be able to transmit communications at the same time as receiving communications from other devices.

The intellecutal merit of the OSTARA project is focused on addressing the challenges facing full-duplex wireless communication. Most existing wireless systems today do not allow for simultaneous transmission and reception of communications at the same frequency. In order to have the ability to transmit and receive at the same time and at the same frequency, it is necessary for a wireless device to employ cancellation that subtracts the transmitted signal from the incoming wireless communication signal that is being received. 

Since simultaneous transmission and reception involves signals that can be considered interference to receivers, the OSTARA project examined both architectures that would allow for high-fidelity subtraction of interference signals at a transmitter/receiver, as well as improved understanding of how interference can be modeled, and how interference can impact communication throughput and communication secrecy.

The OSTARA team approached the problem of subtracting interference using high-fidelity photonic circuits that included photonic filters to cope with amplitude, frequency and phase distortions that exist between the transmission and reception of signals, as well as might exist in photonic components like RF-to-optical modulators. The team developed mathematical models to represent the impact of parameter mismatch upon subtraction fidelity, and thereby upon the ability to perform simultaneous transmission and reception. The team was able to show that, in benign scenarios with limited multipath, it is possible to receive significant subtraction fidelity, thereby suggesting that photonic circuits are suitable for use in building full-duplex wireless transceivers. 

The team also conducted complementary research into understanding the impact that interference can have on a wireless network. Specifically, the team showed that it is possible to accurately model the statistics associated with wireless interference in a multipath environment using more efficient representations. This result can allow for future wireless systems engineers to model wireless network deployments more effectively with less computing resources. Additionally, the team examined the impact that a third party interference source could have on the ability for two parties to communicate. Specifically, the team considered the case where the third party could either interfere or listen on the communications between two parties, and associated an appropriate penalty associated with either case: in one case there is more interference leading to less data being reliably transmitted, while in the other case the data gleaned by the third party is considered to have lost its value and therefore removed from the effective throughput. Algorithms for allocating communication power were derived for such a scenario. This result can be useful to ensuring the secrecy of wireless systems that aim to operate in adversarial settings where it is unknown whether the adversary will cause interference or eavesdrop on communications. Additionally, with minor modifications to the formulation, these results can be useful for ensuring confidential communications involving full-duplex wireless transceivers. In this setting, the recipient uses full-duplex communication to create interference that harms an eavesdropper in conjunction with high-fidelity subtraction circuits that remove self-interference.
